citation.article-title: Rearrangements of the species and genera of the phototrophic "purple nonsulfur bacteria."

p.s: Type species: Rhodocyclus purpureus Pfennig 1978. Other species: Rhodocyclus gelatinosus (Molisch 1907) van Niel 1944 comb. nov. and Rhodocyclus tenuis Pfennig 1969 comb. nov. Formerly, Rhodocyclus tenuis has been included in the genus Rhodospirillum as Rhodospirillum tenue, and Rhodocyclus gelatinosus has been included in the genus Rhodopseudomonas as Rhodopseudomonas gelatinosa.
Cells are slender, curved, 0.3 to 0.7 μm in diameter, and motile by means of polar flagella or nonmotile.
Intracytoplasmic photosynthetic membranes are present in the form of small finger-like intrusions of the cytoplasmic membrane.

Although the species of this genus formerly have been included in three different genera, they show a remarkable degree of similarity to each other and significant differences compared with all other species of the purple nonsulfur bacteria. Rhodocyclus is the sole genus in this group that has only a few tubular intrusions of the cytoplasmic membrane as intracytoplasmic photosynthetic membranes, cytochrome c551, an S-sulfocysteine synthase, and Q-8 and MK-8 as major quinones.
All three species reduce sulfate via adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate.
According to DNA-rRNA hybridization studies and 16s rRNA analyses they form a group that is separate from all other purple nonsulfur bacteria.
The results of these analyses would allow establishment of different genera in a new family apart from the other purple nonsulfur bacteria.
However, the species now placed in the genus Rhodocyclus are surprisingly similar in a number of other properties.
It is obvious that these species have to be placed in a taxon separate from the other purple nonsulfur bacteria.
Because detailed determinative information is lacking to safely distinguish them on the generic level, we propose placing them in the genus Rhodocyclus.
